thread.title: Winter Weather Advisory and Storm Warning issued for Northern California, snow accumulations expected
thread.title_full: Winter Weather Advisory and Storm Warning issued for Northern California, snow accumulations expected

author: Matt Wreden
title: Winter Weather Advisory and Storm Warning issued for Northern California, snow accumulations expected
text:
NORTHERN CALIFORNIA - The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Storm Warning and Winter Weather Advisory for several areas of Northern California, including Shasta Lake, Northern Shasta County, and the Western Plumas County/Lassen Park regions.
These warnings are in effect as severe winter weather is expected to impact the area over the next 48 hours.
Key Details:
Winter Weather Advisory: In effect until 10 p.m. this evening. Additional snow accumulations of six to 10 inches are expected.
Winter Storm Warning: In effect from 4 a.m. Friday, to 10 p.m. Saturday. Heavy snow is anticipated, with total snow accumulations of one to three feet, and locally higher totals over peaks. Winds could gust up to 55 mph.
Areas Affected:
- Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County
- Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County
- Western Plumas County / Lassen Park
- West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada
Impacts:
Travel Difficulties: Hazardous driving conditions are expected due to snow accumulation and gusty winds. Travel could be difficult to impossible, especially during commutes.
Wind Gusts: Winds may reach speeds of 55 mph, which could bring down tree branches and cause further disruption.
Additional Information:
A heavy snowstorm is expected to continue through this evening, followed by another round of moderate to heavy snow from Friday morning through Saturday night, with the heaviest snow expected on Saturday.
Precautionary Measures:
Road Conditions: Travelers are advised to monitor road conditions. Check the latest updates from Caltrans online at quickmap.dot.ca.gov or by dialing 5-1-1.
Residents in the affected areas are urged to prepare for winter conditions and to avoid unnecessary travel during the storm.
